all_summaries: The paper introduces Contrastive Activation Addition (CAA) as a method for steering language models toward specific text properties in adaptive free-form summarization, showing that steering vectors can effectively influence topics, sentiment, readability, and readability, but higher steering strengths degrade text quality. It compares steering with prompting, finding that prompting preserves quality better but offers weaker control, while combining methods yields the best balance of control and quality. The study highlights the trade-off between control efficacy and text quality degradation, suggesting that hybrid approaches are essential for practical applications.

This paper introduces contrastive activation addition (CAA) as a method to steer language models toward specific text properties in adaptive free-form summarization, showing that CAA effectively controls topical focus, sentiment, readability, and toxicity but with trade-offs in text quality as steering strengths increase, and that combining steering with prompting achieves the best balance between control and quality.
